answer_validation.reasoning: For a statically stable aircraft in trimmed flight, the center of pressure (CP) is located behind the center of gravity (CG). When the angle of attack is reduced due to a gust, the lift force decreases, causing the CP to shift forward towards the CG in order to maintain the same pitching moment about the CG and restore the trimmed condition. This is the essence of static longitudinal stability - the aircraft generates a restoring moment that opposes the disturbance.

step_by_step: Identify the key principle: Static longitudinal stability requires the center of pressure to be located behind the center of gravity in trimmed flight.
When the angle of attack is reduced due to a gust, the lift force decreases, causing the CP to shift forward towards the CG.
This forward shift of the CP creates a restoring pitching moment that opposes the initial disturbance and tries to return the aircraft to its trimmed condition.
The forward shift of the CP is necessary to maintain the same pitching moment about the CG and regain equilibrium.

textbook_references.text_snippet: The neutral point serves as an alternative stability criterion. The sign of ∂C/∂α depends on whether the center of gravity location (h) is less than, equal to, or greater than the neutral point location (hₙ). For longitudinal static stability, the center of gravity must be located ahead of the neutral point (h < hₙ).

alternative_methods.name: Analyzing the Pitching Moment Coefficient Curve
alternative_methods.description: Instead of just considering the relative positions of the CP and CG, one can also analyze the pitching moment coefficient curve (C_M vs C_L) to understand static stability. The slope of this curve, dC_M/dC_L, must be negative for static stability.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Provides a more quantitative approach to assessing stability, but requires more mathematical understanding. Complements the conceptual explanation of CP and CG positions.
